Information Sheet on NAEB Utilization Kit Project
February 22, I960
For the past year the NAEB Utilization Committee has been discussing
ways to help their affiliates develop good utilization of their school
broadcasts* There is no "sure fire" formula for using educational broad¬
casts any more than there is for teaching* Utilization technique is some¬
thing a teacher must develop for herself, but there are some things we
can do to help this process*
All of us are acquainted with the frantic search that begins around
the first of May for materials to use with "utilization workshops" to be
held during the summer* This is understandable when you consider that
one of the basic precepts of all utilization courses is familiarization
with the medium and the uses made of it*
Even if we have locally produced materials we need to obtain other
examples of programs and utilization procedures if we are to keep from
becoming hopelessly ingrown. From the committee*s discussions it seemed
obvious that one thing that was universally needed was a readily avail¬
able library of utilization information and materials* To meet this need,
the Utilization Committee is developing kits of material to be made avail¬
able on short term loan from NAEB Headquarters* These utilization demon¬
stration kits will take many different forms* There will be material
specially prepared for use with teacher groups, school administrators,
P.T.A.»s and other community groups* We have not developed a standard
format for these kits but expect to use various media and combinations
of media to tell the story.
In some instances the kits will consist of collections of program
examples, either on tape or film* Others will be specially produced
materials showing some specific type of utilization. Still others will
attempt to define basic terms or objectives*
Some of the ideas proposed in our committee meetings are?
1. A file of sample kinescope or tape recordings of successful school
programs. Along with these films or tapes, study guides, lesson
plans, utilization results, and other printed material would be
furnished*
2* Special edited "kines" showing various aspects of school tele¬
vision programs. For instance, a 30«minute film showing short
examples from different school programs could be put together
from existing material. Other "kines" could be edited to tell
a story. Transitions could be made by inserting special commen¬
tary kinescope recorded footage. Films illustrating the strengths
of television or defining (by illustration) what is meant by
various terms such as "enrichment", "supplementary" and "direct
teaching". The list of such special uses of kinescope programs
is almost limitless*
3* Excerpts from taped radio broadcasts could be put together with
tape transition consnentaries similar to above.
lu Interviews with teachers, supervisors, administrators, pupils,
parents, etc* telling of their experience with educational bread-
casts could be put on film or tape*
